name: nytimes
text:
“I can’t breathe.”

"You gotta take this mask off, dude. Please.”

“I can’t breathe. I can’t breathe. I can’t breathe.”

We found at least 70 people who died in police custody after saying “I can’t breathe” in the past decade. More than half were black. https://t.co/ZwQOKGjXei

name: nytimes
text:
You’ve likely heard of George Floyd and Eric Garner, but you might not know many of the others who died in custody.

In some cases, officers restrained people by the neck, hogtied them, Tased them, or covered their heads with hoods. https://t.co/sBeerAysZk

name: nytimes
text:
Detainees’ words could be heard on audio or video recordings, or were otherwise documented in official witness statements or reports. 

—Willie Ray Banks struggled for air as Texas officers restrained and Tased him in 2011. https://t.co/sBeerAysZk https://t.co/Bh8cjM0asL

name: nytimes
text:
There are others:

—Hector Arreola died in Columbus, Georgia, in 2017 after officers cuffed him on the ground and l… https://t.co/p4P4CD43n2

name: nytimes
text: —Vicente Villela died in an Albuquerque jail in 2019 after guards held him down with their knees. He said he couldn… https://t.co/zH04CBObap

name: nytimes
text: —Fermin Vincent Valenzuela was asphyxiated in 2016 after officers in Anaheim, California, put him in a neck hold wh… https://t.co/hU4EgDgZN2

name: nytimes
text:
Autopsies have repeatedly identified links between the actions of officers and the deaths of detainees who struggled for air.

Only a few officers have faced criminal charges, and almost none have been convicted.

Read more. https://t.co/ZwQOKGjXei
